p: Females show higher antibody response to vaccines, and consequently, vaccine efficacy is high in females [ 56– 58]. For instance, the protective antibody responses against the measles vaccine were twice as high in females compared to males of 11–22 years of age [ 58]. Similar effects have also been observed with other vaccines including rubella, hepatitis, rabies, mumps, yellow fever, and influenza [ 57]. Although females respond better to vaccination, they also show higher adverse reactions including pain, fever, and inflammation to vaccines [ 57]. Interestingly, in the early years (birth to 5 years), males are known to develop more robust immune responses than females [ 51]. This sex-specific differences in immune response in this early stage could be due to differences in immune cell types as young males are known to have a higher percentage of natural killer cells while females have higher CD3 and CD4 cell counts [ 59].
